Willy Vlautin has not been idle since the 2005 release of his sparse masterpiece, The Fitzgerald. There was an album of re-recorded work, showing Richmond FontaineÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢s Portland roots in hardcore; an internet-only live set; and a novel, The Motel Life, which read like a prose version of one of his songs, following two losers round Reno as they waited for their luck to change. 

As the laureate of the lost, the lonely, and the rootless, Vlautin was never likely to stand still, and while there is no dramatic change in the texture of his lyrics, the geography has altered. VlautinÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â€žÂ¢s drifters are still skirting the borders of oblivion, but their tales unfold against a desert backdrop.
